say_hello[source]

say_hello(to)

Say hello to somebody

{% endraw %}

We can use this to say hello to anyone

{% raw %} 
say_hello("Sylvain")

'Hello Sylvain!'
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
assert say_hello("Jeremy")=="Hello Jeremy!"
{% endraw %}

HelloSayer class

By using #exports with an s, this will be exported both in lib and docs.

{% raw %} 
class HelloSayer:
    "Say hello to `to` using `say_hello`"
    def __init__(self, to): self.to = to

    def say(self):
        """
        Do the saying, and it can be a very long proper docstring
        """
        return say_hello(self.to)

    def say_emphasis(self, emphasis):
        """
        Do the saying, and add other things too
        Input:
        emphasis: String
        Output:String
        
        """
        return say_hello(self.to+emphasis)
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

class HelloSayer[source]

HelloSayer(to)

Say hello to to using say_hello

{% endraw %}

By calling show_doc, this will be in the documentation

{% raw %}

HelloSayer.say[source]

HelloSayer.say()

Do the saying, and it can be a very long proper docstring

{% endraw %} {% raw %}

HelloSayer.say_emphasis[source]

HelloSayer.say_emphasis(emphasis)

Do the saying, and add other things too Input: emphasis: String Output:String

{% endraw %}

example

{% raw %} 
o = HelloSayer("Alexis")
o.say()

'Hello Alexis!'
{% endraw %}
